data.text: Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface.
Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version.
Enhance the clarity of the input image.
Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details.
Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness.

Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details.
Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots.
Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values.
Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image.
Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values.
A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data

A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise
Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes.
Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise.
Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects.
Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background.
Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate.
This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video
Converts the size of the input image to a user-specified size.
Choose from Nearest, Linear, Area, Cubic, Lanczos4
Converts a low-resolution input image into a corrected high-resolution image.
Choose from ESPCN, FSRCNN, or LAPSRN.
Choose from x2, x3, or x4.
Cuts the input image to a user-specified size.
Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area.
Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations.
Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale.
Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2.

Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values.
Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness.
Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image.
Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Fills the edges of the image using padding methods.
Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion.
Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE

Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion.
Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
detect straight lines in an input image.
Detect circles in an input image.
Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen.
Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity.
Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color.
Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels.

The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations.
Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences.
Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes.
Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined

Crop Cuts the input image to a user-specified size. Select Area Crop button
Method for Handling Exceptions Choose from Zero padding, Original Version Only
Start of Crop X-value (Default value: 0)
Start of Crop Y-value (Default value: 0)
End of Crop X-value (Default value: 256)
End of Crop Y-value (Default value: 256)
Perspective Transform Transforms the perspective of the image to a user-selected area. Select Area Perspective Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 0)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 256)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 0)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right X-value (Default value:256)
Bottom Right Y-value (Default value:256)
Affine Transform Transforms the input image while preserving the linearity, distance ratio, and parallelism of the image. It supports translations, scaling, rotation, and even shearing and reflection transformations. Select Area Affine Transformation button
Top Left X-value (Default value: 25)
Top Left Y-value (Default value: 25)
Top Right X-value (Default value: 204)
Top Right Y-value (Default value: 25)
Bottom Left X-value (Default value: 128)
Bottom Left Y-value (Default value:204)
Flip Flip the input image. Direction Choose from X-axis, Y-axis, XY-axis.
Translation Translates the input image. X-axis (Default value: 10)
Y-axis (Default value: 10)
Log Polar Transformation Converts from Cartesian to polar coordinates to consistently recognize objects despite changes in rotation or scale. Direction Method Choose from Forward, Inverse
M (Default value: 80.0)
Pyramids Up/Down Applying Gaussian filtering to an image, the pyramid technique adjusts the image size. ‘pyrUp’: x2, ‘pyrDown’: x1/2. Method Choose from Up, Down
Mean Shift Mean shift segmentation using image pyramids on the input image. It involves creating an image pyramid at specified levels, and setting the final values using the average spatial values and average color vectors through the spatial window radius and color window radius. However, due to its high computational demand, effective results require using appropriate image sizes and parameter values. Space Radius (Default value: 2.0)
Color Radius (Default value: 40.0)
Maximum Pyramid Level (Default value: 3)
Arithmetic Operations Multiply/Divide Multiplies or divides the input image by a constant value to increase or decrease brightness. Calculation Method Choose from Multiplication Operation, Division Operation
Calculation Value (Default value: 1.0)
Misc. Noise Generation Generates various noises for the restoration of the input image. Noise type Choose from Gaussian, Exponential, Poisson, Uniform, Impulse, Salt and Pepper, Multi Gaussian, Laplacian
Mean Value (Default value: 0.0)
Standard Deviation (Default value: 100)
Length (Default value: 1000)
Range (Default value: 0.3)
Coefficient (Default value: -20)
Edge Padding Fills the edges of the image using padding methods. Padding generation method Choose from Fill with 0, Edge Value Replication, Mirror, Iteration, Edge Value Exclusion,
Padding width (Default value: 1)
Thresholding Convert pixels brighter than a given threshold to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Range Restriction Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Threshold value (Default value: 90)
Specified Value (Default value: 255)
Adaptive Thresholding Each pixel is compared to the average value of surrounding pixels; if the difference is large, the pixel is treated as an outlier and thresholded accordingly. Pixels brighter than the adapted threshold are converted to white, and all others to black for binary conversion. Threshold Method Choose from Binarization, Binarization Color, Inversion, Crop, Zero-Pointing, Zero-Point Color, nversion, OTSU, TRIANGLE
Adaptive Thresh Method Choose from Average, Gaussian
Mask Size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Maximum value (Default value: 255)
Parameter (Default value: 5)
Hough Line Detection detect straight lines in an input image. Canny: Usage Status Choose from Use, Not Use
Canny: Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7
Canny: Threshold 1 (Default value: 0.2)
Canny: Threshold 2 (Default value: 0.8)
Hough: Type Choose from Standard, Probabilistic, Multi-scale
Hough: Rho (Default value: 1)
Hough: Theta (Default value: 180)
Hough: Threshold Value (Default value: 150)
Hough: Raw Improvement Value(srn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Theta Improvement Value(stn) (Default value: 0)
Hough: Minimum Line Length Value (Default value: 0)
Hough: Maximum Line Gap Value (Default value: 0)
Hough Circle Detection Detect circles in an input image. DP Value (Default value: 2)
Minimum Distance Value (Default value: 100)
PARAM1 value (Default value: 200)
PARAM2 value (Default value: 100)
Minimum radius value (Default value: 10)
Maximum radius value (Default value: 0)
Use of blur Choose from Use, Not Use
Mask size Choose from 3x3, 5x5, 7x7, 9x9, 11x11, 13x13
Grayscale Converts the input color image to a grayscale image.
Color Extraction Extracts the values corresponding to Red, Blue, and Green from the input image and displays them on the screen. Color type Choose from Red, Green, Blue
Contours Detection Finds the contours of an image by identifying boundaries that have the same color or intensity. Use of Threshold Choose from Use, Not Use
Threshold (Default value: 127)
Contour Detection Mode Choose from External, List, Ccomp, Tree
Contour Approximation Method Choose from None, Simple, TC89_L1, TC89_KCOS
Output Method Choose from Origin,
Flood Fill If adjacent pixels are similar to the reference color, fill the entire area with a single color. Staring X (Default value: 0)
Staring Y (Default value: 0)
Low Diff (Default value: 5)
High Diff (Default value: 5)
Color Choose one of 13 colors.
Histogram Equalization Calculate the cumulative sum of the image histogram and normalize it by dividing by the total number of pixels. Histogram Method Choosing from Smoothing, Stretching, Sliding
Sliding Value (Default value: 0)
Fourier Transform The Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is an efficient algorithm that quickly performs the Discrete Fourier Transform and its inverse. It is used in many fields, from digital signal processing to algorithms for solving partial differential equations. Transformation Method Choose from Affine transformation, Inverse transformation
Change Detection Compares a pair of selected images pixel by pixel to detect differences. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Threshold (Default value: 50)
Noise Removal Filter Choose from 1x1, 2x2, 3x3, 4x4, 5x5
View Changes Only Choose from true, false
Change Detection (CNN) Divides a pair of selected images into patches at the same locations and compares them to detect changes. Comparison File Selection Method Choose from Next File, Previous File, User-defined
Comparison File Choose from Image List File
Patch size (Default value: 5)
Threshold (Default value: 50)
View Changes Only Choose from true, false

anchors.text: Apply an embossing effect to the image to accentuate its edges and create the appearance of a raised surface.
Choose from 135, 90, 45, North, West, South, East, Northeast
Transform the input image to a soft or smooth version.
Enhance the clarity of the input image.
Removes low-detail elements from the original image and then reapplies them to enhance the sharpness and clarity of edges and details.
Calculates the median value around each pixel in the image, then replaces that pixel value to preserve edges, reduce noise, and improve image smoothness.

Pixels are eliminated according to the designated alpha value in the image, and the average of the remaining values is calculated, thereby effectively mitigating noise and preserving essential image details.
Used to remove extreme impulse noise or to highlight features based on brightness differences. *Impulse noise: A condition characterized by random scattering of black and white dots.
Max: Removes dark impulse values to brighten.Min: Removes bright impulse values to darken.
Replaces the current pixel value in the input image with a weighted average of itself and its neighboring pixel values.
Detects edges in the input image by calculating gradient (derivative) values.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Detects edges in all directions in the input image, but is more sensitive to edges in diagonal directions and is robust against noise.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Enhances the directional accuracy of the Sobel filter, compensating for its limitations.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Detects vertical and horizontal edges in the input image. It is fast, but its performance might be lower compared to other methods.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Equalizes gradients at horizontal, vertical, and diagonal edges. Easily extracts subtle edge details and produces thinner lines, but may incorrectly detect noise as edges.
Detects only well-defined edges at a very fast speed.
Choose from x-direction, y-direction, x, y directions
Removes low-frequency (minimal change) and emphasizes high-frequency (significant change) to detect sharp edges in all directions of the input image.
Detects edges as a single line by setting upper and lower threshold values.
A corner detection technique that utilizes the minimum eigenvalue in its calculations.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data

A technique that detects corners by moving a small window within the object in the image up, down, left, and right, identifying points where there is a significant change in pixel values within the window.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
A feature detection technique that considers affine transformations for easier tracking.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
A feature extraction technique designed for extreme speed.
Choose from Visualize feature points on the original image, View Feature Point Data
Removes small objects and reduces boundaries in the input image to eliminate unwanted small noise
Expands small objects and enlarges boundaries in the input image to enhance structural features and close small holes.
Apply erosion followed by dilation to remove small white noise.
Apply dilation followed by erosion to fill or remove small black holes in white objects.
Extract small elements and details in the input image, and increase the brightness of objects against a dark background.
Leaves only the outlines of binary image regions. The Gradient = Dilate(src) - Erode(src) is identical to subtracting Erode from Dilate.
This method is primarily used to mitigate noise or damage in an input image or video

tables.preceding_text:
When data files are connected to the Add Node, their names are displayed in the Data Source Priority. There is no limit to the number of data sets that can be added.
In D ata Source Priority, the top data set serves as the main source, to which all other data sets are added. Use the [image:rId71], [image:rId72] buttons to change the rank of a data source.
The "Fields" column lists the variables that will be added when the node is executed. As shown in the image, variables from "data source A~C" are mapped to the "Fields" variables.

data.text: Random Sampling, Systematic Sampling, Stratified Sampling, From the beginning, Stratified Sampling (Equal Partition)
Specify whether you want to use or exclude the extracted data.
Select the discrete variable to be used as the basis for stratified sampling.
Specify the method for determining the sample size.
Set the Percentage of samples for sampling. If the calculated sample count is not an integer, it is roundest to integer
Set the number(count) of samples for sampling

NOTE: Description of the sampling method. Random Extraction: Extract data randomly using tools such as random number tables. Hierarchy Extraction: Order every member of the population, extract one sample randomly, and then extract subsequent samples at fixed intervals. (Note: Only up to 50% of the total data can be sampled. Additionally, if the calculated sampling interval is not an integer, it is rounded to the nearest integer.) Stratified Sampling: Dividing the population into homogeneous subgroups and then randomly sampling from these subgroups based on their sizes.

C olumn Filter Node has the following property configuration

data.text: NOTE: Regular expressions serve as templates to match specific patterns and search terms in data. They are made up of literals (pure letters or numbers), metacharacters (which represent types of characters or character groups), and escape sequences. Literal: When only literals are used, without metacharacters and escapes, their representation is identical to the lemma notation.Example) "Regular expression name John Doe" extracts "John Doe" as a morpheme and assigns it the part of speech "name." Single Character Metacharacters [table:t727_n1] Composite character-type metacharacters [table:t727_n2] Escaping: Unmentioned non-printable characters in metacharacters are also specified by escapes. [table:t727_n3]

data.text: Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions.
Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions.

Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible.
zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."

Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters.
"^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
Locates positions at the end of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions before `\n` or `\r`.
"\d{3}$" finds three digits at the end of the searched string.
Find all single characters except the newline character `\n`. To find all characters, including `\n`, patterns like `[\s\S]` are used.
Square brackets mark the beginning and end of a set, grouping one or more individual characters into a list.
[1-4] finds "1", "2", "3", or "4". [^aAeEiIoOuU] finds any character that is not a vowel.
Quantifiers mark the start and end of an expression and specify the number of times to repeat the sequence when the number of characters cannot be predefined.
Parentheses mark the beginning and end of a subexpression, which can be stored for later use.
A(\d) finds anything from "A0" to "A9", storing the digit for later use.
The pipe symbol represents a choice between two or more items.
z|food finds either "z" or "food". (z|f)ood finds "zood" or "food".
Slashes mark the beginning and end of a literal regular expression pattern. After the second slash, a single character flag can be added to specify search behavior.
/abc/gi is a literal regular expression that finds "abc". The 'g' flag specifies finding all occurrences of the pattern, and the 'i' flag specifies ignoring case during the search.
The following character is indicated as a special character, literal, or octal escape. To search for a single character meta character, you must escape the character.
\n finds a newline character. \( finds "(". \\ finds "\". \+ finds "+".

tables.table_html:
Metacharacters Description Examples
* Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions. "zo*" finds "z" and "zoo."
+ Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. "zo+" finds "zo" and "zoo" but not "z."
? Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible. zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."
^ Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters. "^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
$ Locates positions at the end of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions before `\n` or `\r`. "\d{3}$" finds three digits at the end of the searched string.
. Find all single characters except the newline character `\n`. To find all characters, including `\n`, patterns like `[\s\S]` are used. "a.c" finds "abc," "a1c," and "a-c."
[] Square brackets mark the beginning and end of a set, grouping one or more individual characters into a list. [1-4] finds "1", "2", "3", or "4". [^aAeEiIoOuU] finds any character that is not a vowel.
{} Quantifiers mark the start and end of an expression and specify the number of times to repeat the sequence when the number of characters cannot be predefined. a{2,3} finds "aa" and "aaa".
() Parentheses mark the beginning and end of a subexpression, which can be stored for later use. A(\d) finds anything from "A0" to "A9", storing the digit for later use.
| The pipe symbol represents a choice between two or more items. z|food finds either "z" or "food". (z|f)ood finds "zood" or "food".
/ Slashes mark the beginning and end of a literal regular expression pattern. After the second slash, a single character flag can be added to specify search behavior. /abc/gi is a literal regular expression that finds "abc". The 'g' flag specifies finding all occurrences of the pattern, and the 'i' flag specifies ignoring case during the search.
\ The following character is indicated as a special character, literal, or octal escape. To search for a single character meta character, you must escape the character. \n finds a newline character. \( finds "(". \\ finds "\". \+ finds "+".

anchors.text: Find at least 0 preceding strings or sub-expressions.
Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions.

Find one or more of the preceding strings or subexpressions. When a `?` follows other quantifiers like `*`, `+`, `?`, `{n}`, `{n,}`, or `{n,m}`, the matching pattern becomes non-greedy. Non-greedy patterns seek the smallest possible matching section within the searched string, in contrast to the default greedy patterns, which aim to match as much of the string as possible.
zo? finds "z" and "zo" but not "zoo”. "o+?" finds one "o" in "oooo," while "o+" finds all the "o"s. "do(es)?" finds "do" in both "do" and "does."

Locates positions at the start of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions following `\n` or `\r`. When used as the first character inside brackets, `^` negates the set of characters.
"^\d{3}" finds three digits at the beginning of the searched string. "[^abc]" finds any character except for a, b, and c.
Locates positions at the end of the searched string. When used with the `m` flag for multi-line searching, it also finds positions before `\n` or `\r`.
"\d{3}$" finds three digits at the end of the searched string.
Find all single characters except the newline character `\n`. To find all characters, including `\n`, patterns like `[\s\S]` are used.
Square brackets mark the beginning and end of a set, grouping one or more individual characters into a list.
[1-4] finds "1", "2", "3", or "4". [^aAeEiIoOuU] finds any character that is not a vowel.
Quantifiers mark the start and end of an expression and specify the number of times to repeat the sequence when the number of characters cannot be predefined.
Parentheses mark the beginning and end of a subexpression, which can be stored for later use.
A(\d) finds anything from "A0" to "A9", storing the digit for later use.
The pipe symbol represents a choice between two or more items.
z|food finds either "z" or "food". (z|f)ood finds "zood" or "food".
Slashes mark the beginning and end of a literal regular expression pattern. After the second slash, a single character flag can be added to specify search behavior.
/abc/gi is a literal regular expression that finds "abc". The 'g' flag specifies finding all occurrences of the pattern, and the 'i' flag specifies ignoring case during the search.
The following character is indicated as a special character, literal, or octal escape. To search for a single character meta character, you must escape the character.
\n finds a newline character. \( finds "(". \\ finds "\". \+ finds "+".

data.text: Finds word boundaries, which are positions between a word and a space.
When the searched string is "12 345," "\d{2}" finds "12" and "34." "\d" finds "1," "2," "3," "4," or "5."
When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
Finds all characters except A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and underscores. Same as [^A-Za-z0-9_].
When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
It is a character set. Finds any one of the specified characters.
It is a negated character set. Finds any characters not specified.
It is a character range. Finds characters within a specified range.
"[a-z]" finds lowercase English letters from "a" to "z."
It is a negated character range. Finds any characters not within the specified range.
"[^a-z]" finds all characters that are not in the range "a" to "z."
Finds exactly n occurrences, where n is an integer.
"o{2}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds the two "o"s in "food."
Finds at least n occurrences, where n is an integer. "*" is equivalent to {0,}. "+" is equivalent to {1,}.
"o{2,}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds all the "o"s in "foooood."
Finds at least n and at most m occurrences, where n and m are integers, and n is less than or equal to m. There should be no space between the comma and the numbers. "?" is equivalent to {0,1}.
When the searched string is "1234567," "\d{1,3}" finds "123," "456," and "7."
Finds a pattern and stores the matching items. To find the parenthesis characters ( ), use "\(" or "\)".
"(Chapter|Section) [1-9]" finds "Chapter 5" and stores "Chapter" for later use.
Finds a pattern but does not store the matches. That is, the matches are not saved for later use. This is useful when combining parts of the pattern with the "or" character (|).
It is a positive lookahead. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use.

^(?=.*\d).{4,8}$ ensures a password is between 4-8 characters and includes at least one digit. Within the pattern, ".*\d" finds any number of characters followed by a digit. When the searched string is "abc3qr," it matches "abc3." ".{4,8}" starts from the front, not the back of the match, finding 4-8 characters. This matches "abc3qr." "^" and "$" specify positions at the start and end of the searched string. This ensures that if there are characters outside the matched string, it does not count as a match.

It is a negative lookahead. It finds search strings that do not match the pattern. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use.

"\b(?!th)\w+\b" finds words that do not start with "th." Within the pattern, "\b" finds word boundaries. When the searched string is " quick," it matches the first space. "(?!th)" finds strings that are not "th," matching "qu." "\w+" searches for a word from the front of the match. This matches "quick."
Finds control characters marked with "x". The value of "x" must be within the range of A-Z or a-z. If not, "c" is considered as the literal character "c".
"\cM" finds the Ctrl+M or carriage return character.
Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex.
"\x41" finds "A". "n" must be exactly two digits, so "\x041" is like writing "\x04" followed by "1".
Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex.

Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "n" captured subexpressions before "\n", then "n" is a backreference indicating additional repetitions of the subexpression. If "n" is an octal (0-7) and there are not enough preceding captures, then "n" is an octal escape value.

Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "nm" captured subexpressions before "
m", then "nm" is a backreference. If there are "n" captures before "
m" and a literal "m" follows, then "n" is a backreference followed by literal "m". If none of these conditions are met, "
m" finds the octal escape value "nm", assuming "n" and "m" are octal (0-7).
Finds the octal escape value "nml" where "n" is an octal (0-3) and "m" and "l" are octals (0-7).
Finds "n", where "n" is a Unicode character represented by a four-digit hexadecimal

tables.table_html:
Metacharacters Description Example
\b Finds word boundaries, which are positions between a word and a space. "er\b" finds "er" in "never" but not in "verb."
\B Finds non-word boundaries. "er\B" finds "er" in "verb" but not in "never."
\d Finds digits. Same as [0-9]. When the searched string is "12 345," "\d{2}" finds "12" and "34." "\d" finds "1," "2," "3," "4," or "5."
\D Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. "\D+" finds "abc" and " def" in "abc123 def."
\w Finds non-digit characters. Same as [^0-9]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
\W Finds all characters except A-Z, a-z, 0-9, and underscores. Same as [^A-Za-z0-9_]. When the searched string is "The quick brown fox…," "\W+" finds "…" and all spaces.
[xyz] It is a character set. Finds any one of the specified characters. "[abc]" finds "a" in "plain."
[^xyz] It is a negated character set. Finds any characters not specified. "[^abc]" finds "p," "l," "i," and "n" in "plain."
-a[z] It is a character range. Finds characters within a specified range. "[a-z]" finds lowercase English letters from "a" to "z."
[^a-z] It is a negated character range. Finds any characters not within the specified range. "[^a-z]" finds all characters that are not in the range "a" to "z."
{n} Finds exactly n occurrences, where n is an integer. "o{2}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds the two "o"s in "food."
{n,} Finds at least n occurrences, where n is an integer. "*" is equivalent to {0,}. "+" is equivalent to {1,}. "o{2,}" does not find the "o" in "Bob" but finds all the "o"s in "foooood."
{n,m} Finds at least n and at most m occurrences, where n and m are integers, and n is less than or equal to m. There should be no space between the comma and the numbers. "?" is equivalent to {0,1}. When the searched string is "1234567," "\d{1,3}" finds "123," "456," and "7."
(pattern) Finds a pattern and stores the matching items. To find the parenthesis characters ( ), use "\(" or "\)". "(Chapter|Section) [1-9]" finds "Chapter 5" and stores "Chapter" for later use.
(?:pattern) Finds a pattern but does not store the matches. That is, the matches are not saved for later use. This is useful when combining parts of the pattern with the "or" character (|). "industr(?:y|ies)" is the same as industry|industries.
(?=pattern) It is a positive lookahead. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. ^(?=.*\d).{4,8}$ ensures a password is between 4-8 characters and includes at least one digit. Within the pattern, ".*\d" finds any number of characters followed by a digit. When the searched string is "abc3qr," it matches "abc3." ".{4,8}" starts from the front, not the back of the match, finding 4-8 characters. This matches "abc3qr." "^" and "$" specify positions at the start and end of the searched string. This ensures that if there are characters outside the matched string, it does not count as a match.
(?!pattern) It is a negative lookahead. It finds search strings that do not match the pattern. After finding a match, it starts the search for the next match from in front of the matched text. The matches are not stored for later use. "\b(?!th)\w+\b" finds words that do not start with "th." Within the pattern, "\b" finds word boundaries. When the searched string is " quick," it matches the first space. "(?!th)" finds strings that are not "th," matching "qu." "\w+" searches for a word from the front of the match. This matches "quick."
\cx Finds control characters marked with "x". The value of "x" must be within the range of A-Z or a-z. If not, "c" is considered as the literal character "c". "\cM" finds the Ctrl+M or carriage return character.
\xn Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "\x41" finds "A". "n" must be exactly two digits, so "\x041" is like writing "\x04" followed by "1".
\num Finds "n", where "n" is a hexadecimal escape value. The hexadecimal escape value must be exactly two digits long. ASCII codes can be used in regex. "(.)\1" finds two consecutive identical characters.
\n Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "n" captured subexpressions before "\n", then "n" is a backreference indicating additional repetitions of the subexpression. If "n" is an octal (0-7) and there are not enough preceding captures, then "n" is an octal escape value. "(\d)\1" finds two consecutive identical digits.
\nm Identifies either an octal escape value or a backreference. If there are more than "nm" captured subexpressions before "\nm", then "nm" is a backreference. If there are "n" captures before "\nm" and a literal "m" follows, then "n" is a backreference followed by literal "m". If none of these conditions are met, "\nm" finds the octal escape value "nm", assuming "n" and "m" are octal (0-7). "\11" finds the tab character.
\nml Finds the octal escape value "nml" where "n" is an octal (0-3) and "m" and "l" are octals (0-7). "\011" finds the tab character.
\un Finds "n", where "n" is a Unicode character represented by a four-digit hexadecimal "\u00A9" finds the copyright symbol (©).

NOTE: The meaning of a Bar chart varies based on the variable type. If the variable is continuous, the x-value represents the data index and the y-value represents the corresponding variable value. tables.preceding_text: To visualize word frequency, it is necessary to create two variables: one for the list of words and another for their respective counts. Therefore, use the Tagging Node to generate the variable for words, and apply the Group By Node to create a variable for the counts of these words.

data.text: Neural Network (NN) is a machine learning model with hidden layers to uncover the complex, non-linear relationships between the data. Adaptive Neural Networks (Adaptive NNs) are neural networks that adjust their learning process or structure to suit input data or the learning environment.

data.text: CART (Classification and Regression Trees) is a type of decision tree algorithm. CART is used for Random Forests and Gradient Boosted Trees.

data.text: Decide whether to save model file.
Set the path for the model file to be saved
Specify the impurity function (Default is Gini)

‘Default’ sets the misclassification cost as 1 for correct classifications and 0 for misclassifications across all classes. To assign different costs to each class, select Custom and specify the values.
Occupancy Input refers to the proportion of each class within the data. By default, the same percentage is applied to all classes.
Define whether to build the tree automatically or manually based on the selected options.
Set the minimum number of data required to split a tree node. Activated when the Criterion option is set to ‘Automatic’. (Default is 5)
Choose whether to prune the generated tree. Activated when the Criterion option is set to ‘Automatic’.
The maximum depth of the tree. Activated when the Criterion option is set to ‘Automatic’. Default: None (nodes are expanded until all leaves are pure or contain fewer than Min Samples Split)
A node becomes a stationary node if its impurity is below the specified impurity threshold. Activated when the Criterion option is set to ‘Automatic’.

If the impurity change for a node is below the specified threshold, the node is considered a terminal node. Activated only when the Criterion option is set to ‘Automatic’, and Pruning option is set to ‘No’.

data.text: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is a type of deep learning model that utilizes multiple convolutional and pooling layers to automatically learn features from input images. These features enable CNN to perform tasks such as classification or prediction. CNN excels at understanding the spatial structure within image data, allowing it to identify and extract intricate patterns or structure.

CNN excels at understanding the spatial structure within image data, allowing it to identify and extract intricate patterns or structure.

data.text: LDA (Linear Discriminant Analysis) is a supervised classification algorithm, assuming all classes share a common covariance matrix. It maximizes between-class separation while minimizing within-class variance, resulting in linear decision boundaries.

data.text: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a multivariate technique used for dimension reduction. Principal Component Regression (PCR) is one of regression technique to handle multicollinearity in multiple linear regression. PCA transforms the original variables into a set of uncorrelated components (called principal components) that explains the maximum variance in x-space.

data.text: Partial least squares (PLS) is a statistical method commonly used for dimensionality reduction, regression analysis. PLS is used to analyze data where there is a large correlation between independents or where the number of variables is greater than the number of observations. If there is a multicollinearity problem, PLS reduces the number of predictors by transforming them into latent variables. The application fields are chemometrics, bioinformatics, and finance. About Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and PLS, PLS focuses on explaining variance in both predictors and responses while PCA focuses only on explaining variance in the predictors.

data.text: Deep Q Network (DQN) is a reinforcement learning algorithm that uses a neural network to perform Q-learning. It works by estimating the value of different actions in a given state and selecting the action with the highest value.

data.text: Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) is a reinforcement learning algorithm that uses clipping mechanism to limit the difference between the old and new policies, ensuring updates happen gradually. This allows for more stable and controlled policy improvements compared to traditional reinforcement learning algorithms.

data.text: Scorecard is a modeling method that uses the logistic regression algorithm to calculate the impact of independent variables on the dependent variable (Discrete Type) in the form of a score. This modeling method allows to easily understand the influence of independent variables. It is commonly used in the financial sector for evaluating customer credit scores.

data.text: Self-Organizing Map (SOM) is a neural network algorithm inspired by the structure of the human cerebral cortex, where different regions perform specific functions. SOMs allow high-dimensional data to be visualized and interpreted in lower-dimensional spaces.

SOMs allow high-dimensional data to be visualized and interpreted in lower-dimensional spaces.

data.text: Support Vector Classification (SVC) is based on the Support Vector Machine theory that classifies data with multiple attributes or variables into one of the predetermined classes or categories.

data.text: Decide whether to save model file.
Set the path for the model file to be saved.
Select the type of SVC algorithm.
Set the degree of the polynomial kernel if Kernel Type is POLY. Default is 3
Set the scaling factor of the kernel if Kernel Type is either POLY, RBF, or SIGMOID.
Set the constant term of the kernel if Kernel Type is either POLY or SIGMOID.
Set the Nu value of the SVC(Nu) if Type is SVC(Nu).
The parameter C controls how much you want to avoid misclassifying. Set the C value of the SVC if Type is SVC(C). Default is 1
Estimate the optimal Nu and C values.

Optimal Parameter Estimation Estimate the optimal Nu and C values. Required Yes, No

data.text: Support Vector Regression (SVR) is a regression analysis technique that implies the principles of the SVM algorithms. It is used to determine the degree and the direction of the influence of one are more variables on another variable.

data.text: t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) is a multivariate data analysis technique that visualizes the classification and distribution in low dimensions through non-linear dimensionality reduction. It outperforms traditional linear dimensionality reduction methods, such as PCA and MDS, in visualizing data classification.

tables.table_html: [image:rId589] t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) is a multivariate data analysis technique that visualizes the classification and distribution in low dimensions through non-linear dimensionality reduction. It outperforms traditional linear dimensionality reduction methods, such as PCA and MDS, in visualizing data classification.

anchors.text: t-SNE (t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding) is a multivariate data analysis technique that visualizes the classification and distribution in low dimensions through non-linear dimensionality reduction. It outperforms traditional linear dimensionality reduction methods, such as PCA and MDS, in visualizing data classification.

data.text: Decide whether to save model file.
Set the path for the model file to be saved.
Set the total number of learning iterations.
The value should be between 5 and 50. However, it must be less than 1/3 of the number of input data (number of input matrix rows).
Set the Learning Rate Constant value.
The default is 100, and may be adjusted depending on the case.
The closer the threshold value is to 0, the higher the accuracy, but the longer the calculation time. Set to a real value greater than or equal to 0. Default: 0.5
The Initial Momentum value is used for learning until the Number of Epochs reaches 250. Default: 0.5.
The Final Momentum value is used for learning until the Number of Epochs reaches 250. Default: 0.8
Set the number of lower-dimensional dimensions you want to reduce.
The dimensions that are easiest for visualization are 2D or 3D, so it is usually set to 2 or 3. Default: 2.

tables.table_html:
Property group Property Name Description Misc. Note
Model File Save Model File Decide whether to save model file. Required Yes, No
Model File Path Set the path for the model file to be saved. Conditionally Required
Selection options Execution Count Set the total number of learning iterations. Required integer≥0 Default: 1000
Initial Perplexity Set the initial Perplexity value. Required The value should be between 5 and 50. However, it must be less than 1/3 of the number of input data (number of input matrix rows).
Learning Rate Constant Set the Learning Rate Constant value. Required The default is 100, and may be adjusted depending on the case.
Threshold Set the precision of calculation. Required The closer the threshold value is to 0, the higher the accuracy, but the longer the calculation time. Set to a real value greater than or equal to 0. Default: 0.5
Initial Momentum Set the initial momentum value. Required The Initial Momentum value is used for learning until the Number of Epochs reaches 250. Default: 0.5.
Final Momentum Set the final momentum value. Required The Final Momentum value is used for learning until the Number of Epochs reaches 250. Default: 0.8
Dimension Reduction Set the number of lower-dimensional dimensions you want to reduce. Required The dimensions that are easiest for visualization are 2D or 3D, so it is usually set to 2 or 3. Default: 2.

data.text: Specify the name and path of a file to save.
Specify whether to save a variable name.
Select 'overwrite' in the 'Storage Method' will discard existing data and write new data. If an identical file exists, the data will not be saved, and an error will occur.
Overwrite, Error if a file exists
Select the type of delimiter. Supported delimiters are tab, space, bar, comma, semicolon, and colon. To use a different delimiter, select the 'Other' option.

Choose whether to wrap a string in quotation marks on a file.
Select the variable which is criteria of a file separation. Once the Reference Variable option is defined, refer to <Separated storage method when a reference variable is set> below.
Specify the criteria for separating a file. Options include the number of data entries, the number of files, or the category of the reference variable.
Data Count, Number of Files, Reference Variable by Category
Select this option if file separation is based on the number of files.
Select this option if file separation criteria is based on the number of data entries.
Show the name and type of the variable which is displayed in a table.

<Separated storage method when a reference variable is set> If file separation criteria is based on the number of data entries. For example, the option for the number of data entries to separate takes precedence over a reference variable. If the separation number is set to 10 and the reference variable is set to 'A', data are initially separated based on 10 entries. The 10th and 11th values of variable 'A' are then compared: A. If the values are identical, they are combined to form a set of 11 data entries. B. If the values differ, the 10 data entries are saved separately. After saving, the next group of 10 data entries is separated and processed in the same manner. This process continues, dividing a large data file into multiple smaller files. If file separation criteria is based on the number of files. When setting the number of files, the data separation number must be internally defined to divide the entire dataset. The dataset is divided based on the specified number of files. Example: If 100 rows of data are separated into 6 files, the separation number is 17.

<Separated storage method when a reference variable is set> If file separation criteria is based on the number of data entries. When data files are connected to the Add Node, their names are displayed in the Data Source Priority. There is no limit to the number of data sets that can be added.
In D ata Source Priority, the top data set serves as the main source, to which all other data sets are added. Use the [image:rId71], [image:rId72] buttons to change the rank of a data source.
The "Fields" column lists the variables that will be added when the node is executed. As shown in the image, variables from "data source A~C" are mapped to the "Fields" variables.

Fig. 2. Architecture of LeNet-5, a Convolutional Neural Network, here for digits recognition. Each plane is a feature map, i.e. a set of units
whose weights are constrained to be identical.
inline_images.preceding_text:
Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is a machine learning methodology inspired by the similarities between the patterns of connections among neurons and those found in the visual cortex of animals. It is a type of feed-forward neural network that automatically learns features from images through filter or kernel optimization. CNN is widely used for characterizing and classifying of 2D data, such as images, across various field.
[image:rId321]
The figure above illustrates a CNN architecture, like LeNet-5, using convolutional and subsampling layers to extract features, and fully connected layers for digit recognition.
Convolutional neural networks comprise three primary types of layers.

[image:rId178] Edit Edit the chart’s properties. Also, can open ‘Editing’ window on the chart screen by following steps: right click on the chart → Properties(P)
[image:rId179] Print Print the chart.
[image:rId180] Copy Copy the chart.
[image:rId181] Save Save the chart as an image file.
[image:rId182] Extract Data Extract data from the displayed points. Generate Row Select Node to select displayed points after executing the button.
[image:rId183] Axes Scaling Adjust the scale of X and Y axes equally.
[image:rId184] Indicator Line Activates/deactivates vertical and horizontal indicators that follows the position the mouse points to.
[image:rId185] Mark Tip Activates/deactivates the function that displays a mark of the data point where the mouse points to.
[image:rId186] Mark All Activates/deactivates the function that displays marks of all the data points showing.
[image:rId187] Auto Play Select the desired number of data using the slide bar, then run the button. The slide bar moves automatically and shows selected data. Selectable movement interval times: 1, 5, and 10 seconds.
Use the slide bar to select the data for the desired section, and highlight the selected data in a series color.

A common type of NN is the multilayer feedforward network, which consists of an input layer, one or more hidden layers, and an output layer. In this process, the input signal advances layer-by-layer. Each layer's neurons (or nodes) are connected to those in other layers through connections that have a bias and an adjustable weight. The figure below illustrates the structure of an NN with two hidden layers.
[image:rId275]

[image:rId616]
The ROC curve shows the performance of the generated model.
In the above case, we can see that the QDA model has the lowest sensitivity at a certain specificity. This means that this model has the highest misclassification rate at that specificity, making it the worst of the three models.
If your model's ROC curve is exactly diagonal, this indicates that your modeling has no effect at all. This is because specificity and sensitivity are the same for all classification criteria, so the frequency of diagonal elements in the misclassification matrix is the same as the frequency of off-diagonal elements.

[image:rId182] Extract Data Extract data from the displayed points. Generate Row Select Node to select displayed points after executing the button.

[image:rId184] Indicator Line Activates/deactivates vertical and horizontal indicators that follows the position the mouse points to.
[image:rId185] Mark Tip Activates/deactivates the function that displays a mark of the data point where the mouse points to.
[image:rId186] Mark All Activates/deactivates the function that displays marks of all the data points showing.
